name: 3-ethyldiphenylmethane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 3-ethyldiphenylmethane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The target compound, 3-ethyldiphenylmethane, consists of a phenyl group as a basic unit, with a similar reference compound, benzene, having a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The introduction of another phenyl group (diphenylmethane part) generally increases the molecular symmetry and rigidity, likely resulting in an increase in melting point due to enhanced pi-stacking and van der Waals interactions, estimated at +25 degrees. The ethyl group, being an alkyl chain, is expected to decrease the melting point slightly due to a decrease in symmetry and packing efficiency. The decrease might be approximately -5 degrees. The cumulation of these effects is expected to slightly alter the melting point compared to benzene.

name: 3-ethyldiphenylmethane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The base molecule, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The addition of a diphenylmethane structure increases the planarity and symmetry, which typically raises the melting point due to improved π-π stacking interactions; this could be estimated to add around +30°C. The ethyl group, however, reduces the symmetry and may disrupt optimal molecular packing, which tends to lower the melting point. The effect of an ethyl group might be around -5°C to -10°C. Taking these effects into account, the overall prediction would lean towards an increase, but less than the full effect of the added diphenylmethane due to the perturbation by the ethyl group.

name: 3-ethyldiphenylmethane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for this structure is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. Adding ethyl and methyl groups to the benzene ring typically raises the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. However, the ethyl group being larger than the methyl group, with a longer alkyl chain, increases the molecular weight more significantly but adds flexibility to the molecule which can lower the melting point. The diphenylmethane element provides additional aromatic rings which increases the melting point due to stronger pi-pi interactions between the rings. However, the introduction of alkyl groups can disrupt the crystal lattice, lowering the melting point compared to that of pure polycyclic aromatic compounds. Benzene rings: +60 (Pi stacking and planarity), ethyl group: +5 (molecular weight increase, some crystal lattice disruption), two phenyl groups: +40 each (additional pi stacking); these increases are countered by steric hindrance that likely decreases the melting point: -15 for disrupting the crystal packing and -60 due to added flexibility from the combination of ethyl and methyl groups and overall non-planar geometry.
